answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Yes, crowdfunding sites are growing quickly, and public-service projects are starting to get in. Neighbor.ly is a good example, and Citizinvestor.com is another. Crowdfunding sites look to be diversifying by type, with Kickstarter going more to creatives, Indiegogo to nonprofits, and CircleUp to small retail business.
Chesapeake, VA used Facebook for a playground fundraising project in 2010. The advantage there is that the page, still active, is used for program information. It's at http://www.facebook.com/pages/Help-Rebuild-Fun-Forest-in-Chesapeake-VA/110631095631856 
As the field gets more crowded with projects seeking funding, marketing them gets harder. I haven't seen a guide for marketing public works projects, with tips for identifying target audience and pitching effective prizes. Comic showing this tricky marketing situation: http://xkcd.com/1055/

author: Sylvia Carrillo
text: Does anyone know of alternative or creative funding solutions for park or playground equipment? We are engaging the local school district welding program for barbque pits, however, the playground equipment is  a much more significant investment. Thanks!
